moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. d4: I’ve been using this more often in the last year.
moves.4... Bd7 5. c3: This is the slow, preparatory move that I previously used before 4.d4.
moves.5... a6: Not bad but Bc4 is still an option.  …Nf6 would force Nd2 or maybe Bg5.
moves.6. Ba4: Post-analysis…. Computer much prefers Bc4 but I’m more familiar with the text move.
moves.6... Nf6 7. Bc2: 7.O-O Nxe4 8.Re1 is playable but again, not much experience with it.
moves.7... g6 8. Bg5: In the recent Carlsen-Caruana match there were comments to the effect that this type of move is not best.  Not 100% sure why.  Be3 best??  Anyway, I have intentions to move the DSB around to g3.
moves.8... Bg7 9. O-O: 9.d5 would interfere with his DSB but I wasn’t in the mood for such a closed game after having just played a few.
moves.9... Qc8: Didn’t see that coming.  …h6, …O-O, …Bg4 in my opinion.
moves.10. Qc1: Post-analysis computer doesn’t like it.  Takes away from the central control.  Now I’m 5 vs his 6.
moves.10... Bg4 11. Nbd2: Computer says this is best but I never even considered it’s second suggestion of 11.Qe3 which I probably would have preferred.
moves.11... h6 12. Bh4: Computer considers this a mistake.  12.Be3 best.
moves.12... Bxf3: Completes his plan but frees my position to my advantage.  I’m 5 vs 6 in the centre.
moves.13. Nxf3 g5: He has no intention of opening the centre.
moves.14. Bg3 Nh5 15. Qd1: My Q is no use on c1 anymore.  Wish I could tackle the hole on f5.
moves.15... Nxg3 16. hxg3: Wow the computer prefers fxg3.  Gotta think about that for a while.  The only benefit I see is mobility for the R.  Over the course of the game it would not have mattered.
moves.16... g4 17. Nh4: 17.Nh4 is a plan to get to f5, block his Q from g4 and get my Q in his k-side.  Of course it’s a result of his text move which technically is a mistake. +1.09 (better is 16...exd4 or 16...d5)
moves.18. Nf5 Bf6: Computer suggests awkward moves like …Rh7 or …Kf8.
moves.19. Bb3: I don’t have any notes on this but computer doesn’t list it as much of an option.  Seems obvious enough aiming at f7.
moves.19... exd4 20. cxd4 Qd7 21. f3: 21.f3 to open up the k-side but might fail to ...Bxd4+ we'll see if he takes the trap.  Nope so I focus on the weak c6 square with Rc1.  He needs to improve on his K-side attack.  At move 21 the computer had a complicated plan to fake a pin on the Q & K to bring the pawn out.  Too deep for me, didn’t see it.  Plus the computer must be thinking it’s a mistake to open the h-file for my opponent.  - / +
moves.23... Kb8 24. Ba4 b5 25. Bb3 Rh7 26. Qd2: 26.Qd2 I'm stuck. Might try d5.  His double R on the h-file would look gnarly.  Dunno why he plays his next move.
moves.26... Re8 27. Qc3: 27.Qc3 back to the c6 square.  And holy cow the computer analyses 27…Qxf5 as the best follow-up move.
moves.29... Rxf4 30. gxf4 c6 31. Qd3 Kb7 32. N: 32.Nxd6+ screw it. Discovered attack on the R looks pretty so I jumped at it before analyzing.  With 31…Kb7 he must have wanted to relieve his N but missed that it put him into a fork.
moves.37... Bd4 38. axb5 axb5 39. Kh2: Keep my K from being pinned down.
moves.45... Ne5 46. Be6 c4: 46...c4 takes that square from his N so 47.Rxg3 and I'm boss!
moves.47. Rxg3 Nd3 48. Rg6: 48.Rg6 (...Nc5 49.Kd4/Kd5 +/-) Nf4 49.Rh6 Nxe6 50.Rh6 and if Nxg2 then 51.Bh3+ attacking the N.
moves.50... Kc6 51. Bxc4 Nf2+ 52. Kf3: 52.Kf3 (not Kf5 which is OK to keep opposition on his K) maintains the scope of my R (53.Rb5!) and pressures his N.
moves.52... Nd1 53. Rh5 Nb2 54. Bf7 Nd3: 54...Nd3 at this point acenlv took first place with a win over bcjuk but we could all tie at 4 points if I win this.

opening: Ruy Lopez (C62), old Steinitz defence, Nimzovich attack
